title: Is there a written equivalent to ambient music? - Quora

response.answer_text: How about this nature-descriptive classical Chinese poem? It was written by Wang Wei, a poet living in the era of the Tang dynasty (8th century). He was also a musician and a painter of nature. So here you have it: soothing the mind through the description of his surroundings, without a need for a storyline, in a written form. Try to read it with some ambient or repetitive music played in the background and see how it works out. Twenty-nine of his poems were included in a compilation called ‘Three hundred Tang poems.’ I haven’t seen the book yet, but I suspect that reading them would have a similar effect on your mind as listening to hours of ambient music - with the possible addition of some ancient wisdom. Passing the Incense Temple Unknowing on a journey Deep into the cloudy peaks Alone among ancient trees A distant bell resounds Down a steep rocky path The mountain stream tumbles Through a dim pine glade In the fading light of day Before rounding a bend It settles in a pool of quiet Where the peace-filled mind At last stills the lashing dragon

It sounds like you need an extremely picturesque poem, but it's hard to think of something that is ultimately “ambivalent.” That feels insulting in a way, so I am hesitant to call anything that. I suppose, if I think of it, there's one I feel okay with. The band Tool writes lyrics that are brilliant and match difficult time signatures, so I'd recommend looking up Maynard James Keenan and words he writes. He has a knack for matching music that is difficult to match!
